To achieve the purification of coke oven gas and pyrolysis gas under oxygen-free conditions, the MnO2/La2O3/rGO composite catalyst was innovatively loaded directly onto the surface of porous titanium mesh anode by electrodeposition in this study, together with corona discharge for toluene cracking. During the catalyst preparation, the effects of potential and pH on the catalyst were verified in combination with cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves. The results showed that the toluene cracking rate reached 90% at 7 kV when the electrolyte concentrations of Mn2+, La3+ and rGO were 0.1 mol/L, 0.05 mol/L and 0.005 g/L, respectively. In addition, in this study, the distribution and changes of potential and electron temperature inside the reactor were simulated by COMSOL, and the concentration and change pattern of positive and negative ions at 7 kV were calculated. The results showed that both the plasma and the catalyst play a very significant role in this process. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Electrocatalytic crack Corona discharge MnO2/La2O3/rGO Electrodeposition COMSOL simulation Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Coal coking cracks coal at high temperature under oxygen-free conditions to form untreated gases. This gas contains a large amount of coal dust, hydrogen sulfide, tar and other polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons [1,2]. The gas is purified by each purification unit, and the active ingredients in the untreated gases are separated and utilized in the process. When the coal is loaded into the coke oven, about 20–35% of the volatiles are emitted as gases and vapors, most of which are collected in the by-product coke production [3]. If the tar in the untreated gases is not separated efficiently, it will lead to blockage of the pipeline, causing problems such as rising pipe of the coke oven and smoke from the furnace body, and also cause catalyst poisoning and deactivation of the subsequent gas purification process as the tar enters the next stage with the gas. At the same time, if the polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in the waste gas are not removed in time, it will affect the product quality of the subsequent process and cause more pollution emission[4,5]. Conditions such as lack of oxygen and low water content limit the separation and conversion of tar in untreated gases. The commonly used physical methods can only capture tar, and the captured tar is difficult to be separated and treated, which is easy to form secondary pollution, and the energy in the tar cannot be fully utilized [6]. And chemical methods such as thermal cracking and catalytic degradation require higher reaction temperature and residence time, and cracking gas below 180 °C requires higher temperature and residence time, which increases the reaction cost and reduces the safety performance of the reaction [7–9]. The use of catalysts is limited by several unfavorable factors including process complexity, catalyst deactivation due to sintering and/or carbon buildup, poisoning, fouling and regeneration [10,11]. Therefore, the removal of tar under oxygen-free conditions remains a major challenge due to the complex nature of tar and the lack of mature and effective technologies. Tar contains hundreds of compounds and more than a hundred aromatics, of which more than 60 wt% are benzene and its derivatives, mainly toluene. Toluene, as the most representative organic macromolecule with highest content, toxicity and active chemical properties, has been selected as a model compound for tar in many studies to simplify the research process and has strong practical research significance [12,13]. Therefore, toluene was selected as a substitute for tar in this study. Under N2 atmosphere, corona discharge plasma technology generates a great number of active particles and unstable radicals (N, N2) through the collision of high-energy electrons, thus cracking large-molecule organic into small-molecule gaseous products with low energy consumption [14]. The thermodynamic state of low-temperature plasma is non-equilibrium, so air pollutants can be transformed at ambient temperature and pressure. Some studies have shown the success of corona plasma technology for the degradation of organic waste gases [15,16]. However, the high-energy electrons and reactive radicals generated by corona discharge have indiscriminate cracking properties, producing abundant cracking by-products that are difficult to control, and the discharge process is unstable and prone to breakdown at high voltage, thus limiting its application in industry [17]. The composite technology coupled with catalyst can alleviate the problem of complex cracking by-products, while the catalyst can improve the current discharge and alleviate the discharge instability to some extent. Faisal Saleem et al. [18]used CO2 and H2 as carrier gases to crack benzene in a non-thermal plasma (NTP) dielectric barrier discharge reactor (DBD). The results show that CH4(82%) and C2 (C2H6 +C2H4) are the main low hydrocarbons in the pyrolysis products at 400 °C. Liu et al. [19]used Ni- and Fe-based steam reforming catalysts supported on CaO, SiO2, γ-Al2O3 and ZSM-5 were combined with a coaxial dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) plasma reactor to convert toluene. The results shows that the maximum toluene conversion was 86.5%. Xu et al. [20]investigate the TiO2/NiWO4-Ni5TiO7 film to removal naphthalene. The results shows that naphthalene conversion rate of 63% is achieved at 800 °C with a short residence time of 0.34 s and a high tar load of 75 g/mN3. Therefore, non-thermal plasma-coupled catalyst technology may be a promising and attractive way to produce relatively clean product gases. In order to improve the cracking rate of tar and control the use cost, the transition metal oxide MnO2 realizes electron transfer through the change of valence state between Mn4+ and Mn3+, and has high catalytic activity due to the defects of crystal structure and abundant lattice oxygen on the surface of MnO2, so it has attracted the attention of many scholars. Li et al. [21]investigated the VOCs degradation rate for the MnO2 catalysts with different phase structure in a post plasma-catalysis system. Results showed that α-MnO2 was superior to β-MnO2 and γ-MnO2 with respect to the degradation efficiency, the carbon dioxide selectivity and ozone suppression. Zeng et al. [22]Investigate the mechanism of Cu doped MnO2 catalysts to degrade ketone-type VOCs in a one-stage plasma-catalysis system. They believed that the synergistic effect between Cu and Mn in Cu-Mn solid solution can promote the amount of surface active oxygen and reducibility to improve catalytic performance. Wang et al.[23] use the Bi2MoO6-MnO2 for the degradation of EA. The results indicated that A synergetic effect between Bi2MoO6 and MnO2 evidently occurred, showing that h+ generated from Bi2MoO6 by “pseudo photocatalysis” can induce the transformation of Mn3+ to Mn4+ of MnO2 in plasma. However, carbon deposition is inevitable in the process of high-pressure cracking of organic macromolecules, and carbon deposition on the surface of the catalyst can lead to catalyst inactivation. To reduce the effect of carbon deposition on the active site, new components are often introduced into the catalyst to generate carbon deposition on the surface. La2O3 is widely used in the process of syngas to avoid the formation of carbon deposition. La2O3 can adsorb CO through the surface lattice and further combine to form La2O2CO3, thus reducing the further conversion of CO to carbon deposition covering the surface of the catalyst[24]. Fawaz S. Al-Sultan et al.[25] Nanosized gold deposited bare and sulfated La2O3 samples were synthesized and utilized for catalytic oxidative cracking of n-propane. Gold supported sulfated La2O3 catalyst showed stable activity even after 20 h and the catalysts are resilient to formation of the coke. Xu et al.[26] used Ni/La2O3 catalysts for dry reforming, the results showed that the interfaces between Ni and La2O2CO3 can be enlarged, the interfaces between Ni and La2O2CO3 can be enlarged. At the same time, to further alleviate the non-uniform voltage distribution and to avoid breakdown and localized overheating in the process of corona discharge, MnO2 and La2O3 were directly loaded on the catalytic electrodes by the electrodeposition method in this study, which can effectively improve the electron transfer between the catalysts and effectively control the current distribution. In of the catalytic anode, rGO with high conductivity was added to the electrolyte to adjust the conductive performance of the catalytic anode, so as to achieve un`iform current distribution and improve the overall conductive performance. In addition, the pipeline corona discharge method can avoid the risk of tip discharge breakdown, increase the catalytic anode catalytic reaction area, and greatly improve the efficiency of tar cracking. Compared with the catalyst packed bed, it has the advantages of small amount of catalyst, easy preparation, high efficiency and easy control. In this study, a novel toluene cracking technology coupled with anode-supported catalyst and plasma under anaerobic conditions was proposed to solve the problem of tar cracking and conversion under anaerobic environment. At the same time, the cracking process was analyzed in detail by COMSOL simulation, and the mechanism of mutual promotion between catalyst and plasma was deeply analyzed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Experimental setup The experimental setup is shown in Fig. 1, including a toluene gas supply system, a homemade corona discharge reactor, a high-voltage power supply and a flue gas detection system. The detailed structure of the cylindrical corona discharge reactor is shown in Fig. S1. Gaseous toluene is passed through liquid toluene by a dry N2 stream, liquid toluene was contained in a bubbler in a water bath (20 ℃). The N2 gas is regulated by a mass flow meter (CS200, Beijing Sevenstar Electronics Co.,Ltd. SZ：002371), the gas passes through the mixer and enters the reactor from the bottom of the reactor for corona discharge. On-line analysis of toluene degradation rate and some degradation products by gas chromatograph (GC 1120, Sunny Hengping Instrument Co., Shanghai) with flame ionization detector (FID, flame ionization detector). By adjusting the N2 flow rate, the toluene inlet concentration was controlled to about 500 ppm, and the total flow rate was controlled to 600 mL/min. The homemade corona discharge reactor is cylindrical in shape, with a shell made of insulated Plexiglas and a tube - wire corona discharge area inside. The tube anode is enclosed by 100 mesh titanium net. The cathode consists of three stainless steel rods with a diameter of 0.2 mm. The three stainless steel rods are connected by wires and evenly distributed around the corona anode. The spacing between the cathodes and anodes is 2 cm and the lengths are all 15 cm. The anode is a catalytic electrode, and different substrates are selected to load different catalysts to achieve efficient degradation of toluene. This experiment uses a DC high-voltage power supply with output voltage range 0–50 kV and current 0–5 mA. 2.2 Catalysts anode preparation and analysis The catalyst was prepared by electrochemical deposition directly on the electrode substrate, and the electrodeposition process was in a three-electrode system. The working electrode was a 100-mesh titanium net, the counter electrode was a graphite sheet of similar size to the titanium mesh, and the reference electrode was a saturated glycury electrode. The working electrode was first sonicated in dilute hydrochloric acid, distilled water, acetone and distilled water for 30 min to remove surface oxides and oil. The deposition is then performed at 1.5 V using a constant potential deposition method using the electrochemical workstation (CHI660C, Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Co.). Finally, the resulting electrodes were rinsed with deionized water to remove the residual electrolyte on the electrode surface and dried in a drying oven at 60 ℃ for 1 h. Here, the elemental composition, surface metal valence and microstructural features of the catalytic anode were analyzed by utilizing X-ray diffraction (XRD, X′Pert PRO MPD，PANalytical，Netherlands), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific ESCALAB Xi+, USA), scanning electron microscopy (SEM, ZEISS Sigma 300, Germany) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, ZEISS Sigma 300, Germany). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Cyclic voltammetric curve of electrochemical deposition 3.1.1 MnO2 electrochemical deposition The MnO2/La2O3/rGO catalyst is prepared by mixed electrodeposition. As MnO2 is the main deposition of metal oxides, the best conditions of its electrodeposition process are first explored, so as to determine the best conditions of mixed catalyst. MnO2 deposition was performed in a mixed solution of MnSO4 and Na2SO4 using a constant potential deposition method according to previous studies[27–29]. The optimum Mn2+ concentration and pH were tested and the electrodeposition process was verified using cyclic voltammetric curves (CV curves). Based on the information such as the position of the redox peak and the peak current appearing on the CV curve, it is possible to determine the electrochemical reaction occurring in the electrode and the reversibility of the reaction, etc. Fig. 2(a)-(b) shows the CV curves at different pH and MnSO4 concentrations. Fig. 2(a) shows the CV curves for different MnSO4 concentrations. When the voltage is scanned from 0 V to 2 V, an oxidation reaction occurs on the surface of the working electrode, and an oxidation peak appears in the interval of 1.1–1.5 V, which corresponds to the oxidation reaction of Mn2+ ions to MnO2. When the voltage is scanned from 2 V to 0 V, a reduction reaction occurs at the working electrode, and a reduction peak appears in the interval of 0.3 V, which corresponds to the reduction reaction of MnO2 to MnOOH [27,30]. Oxidation reaction process is mainly as follows: Mn2++2 H2O→MnO2 + 4 H++2e- Reduction process is mainly: MnO2+H++e-→MnOOH 2MnO2+H2O+2e-→Mn2O3+2OH- It can be seen from the CV curve that the response current of Mn2+ oxidation to MnO2 is the largest at the Mn2+ concentration of 0.1 mol/L. It indicates that the MnO2 loading capacity is the strongest at this concentration and the highest loading strength is the most tightly bonded with the titanium network. Therefore, 0.1 mol/L MnSO4 was chosen as the concentration of plating solution. To further determine the influence of pH during MnO2 electrodeposition, the optimal pH was determined by scanning in the range of 0.6–2 V using square-wave CV. Fig. 2(b) shows the square-wave CV curves at different pH with a sweep rate of 80 mV/s and Mn2+ concentration of 0.1 mol/L. It can be seen that the response current gradually becomes larger as the pH increases and reaches the maximum at 3.5. Meanwhile, the peak voltage increased with increasing pH, proving that pH has an effect on the Mn2+ oxidation potential. Therefore, the migration rate of Mn2+ in solution is the largest at pH 3.5, and the rate of oxidation to form MnOOH is the fastest, so pH 3.5 is chosen for loading MnO2. 3.1.2 MnO2/La2O3/rGO electrochemical deposition The mixed electrodeposition method is to mix ultrafine solid particles and metal solution evenly under a certain pH, so that the solid particles form a super dispersed system in the solution, to ensure that the metal ions and solid particles adsorb each other, forming a mixed whole, the whole is charged, and then the solid particles and metal ions as a whole move to the electrode surface under a fixed voltage for electrodeposition. The electrodeposition of MnO2/La2O3/rGO catalysts was carried out under the optimum conditions of MnO2 electrodeposition. The mixed plating solution was obtained by sequentially adding rGO and La(NO3)3.6 H2O, to the electrolyte with pH= 3.5 Mn2+concentration of 0.1 mol/L and sonicating for 30 min. Ensure that the rGO concentration is 0.005 g/L and the La3+ concentration is 0.05 mol/L to prepare Ti-MnO2/La2O3, Ti-MnO2/rGO, Ti-MnO2/La2O3/rGO electrodes. Fig. 3 shows the CV curves of Ti-MnO2, Ti-MnO2/rGO, Ti-MnO2/La2O3/rGO at pH= 3.5, sweep rate of 80 mV/s, and Mn2+ concentration of 0.1 mol/L. An oxidation peak in the range of 0.7–1.1 V appears after increasing rGO, indicating that the redox reaction of rGO can occur at the electrode surface under the action of voltage. The addition of metal La3+ increases the oxidation potential of Mn2+, and the CV curve appears as a clear and smooth broad oxidation peak in the range of 0.7–1.5 V, which connects the oxidation peaks of Mn2+ and La3+. It indicates that the addition of La3+ improves the crystallization process of the electrodeposition process, adjusts the current distribution, the electron transfer is more obvious, the electrochemical deposition process is enhanced. 3.2 Structure, composition and morphology To investigate the effect of electrodeposition, the crystal structure and chemical composition of the as-prepared catalysts were characterized by XRD，SEM-EDS and XPS. The XRD pattern (Fig. S2) indicated the successful synthesis of MnO2 and La2O3, along with the presence of some perovskite crystallites. It is difficult to detect MnO2 and La2O3 by XRD because of their dispersed structure and small grains [31,32], thus failing to have a clear main peak in the XRD results, similar to the electrodeposition results of some studies. The SEM images ( Fig. 4(a)-(d)) showed that the thick active ingredient was successfully loaded on the surface of Ti mesh, indicating a significant electrodeposition effect. The rGO was adsorbed on the electrode surface, and MnO2 was mainly dispersed in the form of small particles on the electrode surface and around the rGO; Unevenly formed large crystals on the electrode surface due to the addition of La2O3, indicating that the addition of La2O3 adjusts the crystal structure, which is consistent with the XRD results. The XRD and SEM results showed that the catalyst surface contained many defects with high catalytic activity. The EDS results (Fig. S3) show that La and Mn are uniformly distributed on the electrode surface and the Mn content is much higher than the La content, which is consistent with the reality. Table 1 shows the content and percentage of each element on the catalytic anode surface. Furthermore, the presence of constituent elements of Ti- MnO2/La2O3/rGO containing Mn, C, La and O were identified from the survey scan during XPS analysis ( Fig. 5(a)). Fig. 5(b) shows the XPS spectra of O 1 s for the catalysts. Different oxygen species can be found at the surface of the catalysts: The peak with lower BE value at 528.9–529.2 eV is generally accepted as the lattice oxygen (Olat), the 531.0–531.8 eV is due to hydroxyl groups and/or adsorbed oxygen species (Oads), and adsorbed water H2O (at about 532 eV) [33,34]. Fig. 5(c) shows the XPS spectra of Mn 2p for the catalysts. The Mn 2p3/2 peak can be deconvoluted into two components at BE = 641.8 and 644.5 eV whereas the Mn 2p1/2 peak into two components at BE = 653.6 and 656.3 eV. The components at BE = 641.8 and 653.6 eV can be assigned to Mn3+, while those at BE = 644.5 and 656.3 eV to Mn4+ [35,36]. The XPS spectra of La 3d are mainly composed of the spin–orbit splitting of La 3d5/2 and La 3d3/2 are illustrated in Fig. 5(d). Two characteristic peaks located at 835.4 eV and 838.9 eV are assigned to the La 3d5/2, and two other peaks centered at 852.2 eV and 855.5 eV correspond to the La 3d3/2. The peaks composed of La3d3/2 and La3d5/2 due to spin-orbit coupling were assigned to La species in La2O3 [37,38]. 3.3 Toluene cracking performance 3.3.1 Effect of anode loaded catalyst type on toluene cracking Different catalysts were electrodeposited on the surface of porous titanium mesh. The preparation time of electrodeposition was 30 min for all three catalytic anodes to ensure the consistent Mn2+ concentration in the plating solution. The toluene cracking efficiencies of Ti mash, Ti/rGO, Ti-MnO2, Ti-MnO2/rGO, and Ti-MnO2/La2O3/rGO were compared by varying the DC voltage (0–150 kV) and applying the specific input energy (SIE) in the range of 0–200 J/L. The specific input energy (SIE) was defined by (1) SIE J L = P W Q L / s where Q is the feed gas flow rate, P is the discharge power (W) in the plasma reactor. Under N2 atmosphere, high-energy electrons generated by the cathode will crack N2 to form a variety of active radicals (N * , N2 *, etc.), see reaction Eqs. (2)–(8). High-energy electrons and high-energy radicals have extremely high energy and can crack toluene into small organic molecules, while small molecules combine with high-energy electrons to generate a variety of organic radical small molecules. Organic radical small molecules further cracking toluene and other macromolecules are further cleaved by organic radicals, so that chain reaction occurs to achieve rapid and efficient cleavage of toluene[23,39–41]. (2) N2+e→N2•+e (3) N2+e→N•+N•+e (4) N2+e→N2 - (5) N2+e→N2 ++2e (6) N2+N2+e→N2 - +N2 (7) N2 ++e→N2 (8) N2 ++N2-→2 N2 The results are shown in Fig. 6(a)-(b), the degradation efficiency of toluene by porous Ti mesh was about 60% under different voltages, and slightly increased with the increase of voltage. This indicates that the background value is relatively stable without catalyst, and the degradation of toluene by plasma is limited. Addition of each component promoted the cleavage of toluene. Ti-MnO2/La2O3/rGO showed the best degradation efficiency for toluene at any voltage intensity and specific input energy, and the degradation rate could reach 90% when the voltage was 7 kV. The toluene cracking efficiency decreased significantly when the voltage was increased to 8 kV. This was attributed to the enhanced substrate current, the high resistance values of MnO2 and La2O3 caused the catalyst surface temperature to increase and even burnt[42]. Meanwhile, coke by-product deposition also blocked the active pores. To improve the sintering situation, rGO was added to the catalyst. rGO was uniformly distributed and connected between MnO2 and La2O3 crystals as seen from the SEM-EDS results, which resulted in a uniform current distribution on the surface of the catalytic anode and a reduction of localized superheated sintering. The Ti mash, Ti-MnO2 catalytic anode has been burnt and gradually lost its catalytic activity after the voltage was increased to 9–10 kV. However, the Ti/rGO and Ti-MnO2/rGO were still functioning, indicating that the addition of rGO can effectively improve the efficiency of toluene cracking. The toluene degradation rate tended to increase with increasing SIE (Fig. 6(b)), and the performance of different catalytic anodes again verified the effect of different compositions of the catalysts. The toluene degradation rate slowed down after SIE exceeded 175 J/L, which was attributed to the fact that the doubled electrons in the plasma reactor converted more energy into photons, heat, and resulted in the formation of atoms and sub-stabilized by-products [43]. After the catalytic anode was loaded with MnO2, the toluene cracking rate increased significantly, indicating that the catalyst MnO2 played an important role in the cracking process. The role of MnO2 is mainly in the following aspects: (1) MnO2 acts as a catalytic active center to transfer electrons through the valence change between Mn3+ and Mn4+, and high-energy electrons in the reaction can directly crack toluene [35]. (2) The transfer of high-energy electrons on the surface of MnO2 stimulates the generation of free radicals to a greater extent, and the active radicals crack toluene indirectly. (3) The lattice oxygen in MnO2 has strong catalytic oxidation activity and can catalyze the cleavage of toluene adsorbed on the catalyst surface [44]. Cracking of toluene under high pressure is highly susceptible to carbon deposition covering the active sites of the catalyst. La2O3 as a basic oxide can effectively control the generation of carbon deposition. La2O3 can combine with carbon deposition precursors (C2H2, C2H4, C3H4, C3H6, etc.) to generate La2O3CxHy, which will have a chain reaction with the electrode substrate Ti and release the CxHy bound on the surface of La2O3 [25,26,45,46]. Therefore, the combination of MnO2 and La2O3 can effectively improve the cracking efficiency and facilitate the efficient operation of the catalyst for a long time. 3.3.2 Effect of catalyst components on toluene cracking To further test the above conjecture, investigate role played by different components of the anode catalyst in the cracking. The catalyst composition and ratio on the catalytic anode surface were controlled by adjusting the electrolyte composition and electrodeposition time. Comparison of toluene cracking with different composition ratios, and the results are shown in Fig. 7(a)-(c). Fig. 7(a) shows the catalytic cracking efficiency of toluene at different La3+ concentrations. Keeping the concentrations of Mn2+ and rGO in the electrolyte constant, the catalytic anodes were prepared by electrodeposition under different La3+ concentrations for 30 min. The cracking rate of 70% can be maintained within 120 min. As the concentration of La3+ in the electrolyte increased, the cracking efficiency decreased. Comparing the SEM images of the catalytic anode surface before and after the addition of La3+ in electrolyte. It can be seen that the addition of La3+ has obvious grain generation on the catalyst surface, which is illustrated by the EDS results that the grains contain Mn and La and O. This indicates that the addition of La3+ can effectively adjust the catalyst structure and improve the defects of poor crystallinity in the electrodeposition process (SEM results are shown in Fig. 7(b)-(c)). And increasing the La3+ concentration leads to the intensification of the reaction of La3+ oxidation to generate La2O3, which competes with Mn2+ for the deposition sites during electrodeposition. This leads to a small amount and uneven distribution of the generated MnO2, which greatly reduces the catalytic activity. The XPS results of catalytic anodes prepared with different La3+ ions were also analyzed. As seen in Table 2, the content of Olat/Oads increases from 0.1531 to 0.4411 as La3+ concentration increases from 0.01 mol/L to 0.05 mol/L, When La3+ concentration reaches 0.09 mol/L, Olat/Oads decreases. Indicating that 0.05 mol/L is the most appropriate ratio. Oxygen vacancies can promote the adsorption and activation of oxygen at the active site and facilitate the ORR process. Meanwhile, the Mn4+/Mn3+ ratio on the catalyst surface increased with the increase of La3+ concentration. MnO2 is more likely to generate free radicals than Mn2O3, and MnO2 is more favorable for surface electron transfer. Therefore, the larger Mn4+/Mn3+ is more favorable for toluene cracking. At the La3+ concentration of 0.05 mol/L, Mn4+/Mn3+ reached 71.34%, indicating that the catalyst obtained when the La3+ concentration was 0.05 mol/L had a stronger cracking ability and more active surface electron transfer. Fig. 8(a) shows the degradation of toluene by the catalytic anode with different number of electrical scans of MnO2. the higher the number of scans during deposition, the higher the loading. From Fig. 8(a), the catalyst prepared with 900 scans has the highest degradation rate of toluene. It can see from the CV curve, the Mn2+ deposition potential is higher compared to La3+ and rGO, so oxidation of Mn2+ on the surface of the titanium mesh more quickly. The higher the number of scans, the higher the percentage of MnO2 on the catalytic anode surface. This leads to Mn2+ concentration preemption of the electrodeposition sites and reduced deposition of La3+ and rGO during the electrodeposition process. The small amount of La2O3 leads to the generation of carbon deposition on the catalyst surface, which covers the active sites. And the reduction of rGO led to the local sintering of the catalyst under high pressure and the decrease of catalytic activity. Therefore, an optimal ratio of MnO2, La2O3, rGO exists. Meanwhile, related reports indicate that the introduction of catalyst can improve the plasma generated by corona discharge, which results in more reactive radicals. Under oxygen-free conditions, the generation of sufficient reactive radicals and reactive species can greatly improve the reaction rate, and the generation of organic radicals can be accelerated with the assistance of MnO2 catalyst. The reaction is given by the following equation[18,19,47]. Image 1 (9). Image 2 (10). Image 3 (11). Image 4 (12). Image 5 (13). Image 6 (14). Since both MnO2 and La2O3 are metal oxides, they have high resistivity. Thus, a lower current can also generate a higher heat. The catalytic anode under high pressure is extremely prone to sintering and a distinct burnt smell can be smelled after the reaction. To improve the problem of catalyst sintering and deactivation, rGO was added to the catalyst in this study to improve the conductivity of the catalytic anode surface. To further discuss the role played in different rGO and adjust the optimal concentration, Different concentrations of rGO were added to the electrolyte and sonicated for 30 min to make them fully dispersed in the electrolyte and stable without falling. Toluene cracking experiments were carried out on the catalytic anode after electrodeposition, and the results are shown in Fig. 8(b). The highest activity of the catalytic anode was obtained by electrodeposition at the addition amount of 0.005 g. The addition of rGO improves the conductivity of the catalytic anode, reduces the compound of catalytic current during the catalytic process, makes the current distribution more uniform, and increases the catalytic activity of the electrode. At the same time, the electrode conductivity is improved, which reduces the heat production of the electrode under high pressure and reduces the electrode being sintered. Increasing the concentration of rGO during the plating process instead makes its loading on the electrode no longer obvious, while too much rGO will lead to cover the catalytic sites, and therefore the catalytic activity is reduced. 3.3.3 Effect of voltage on toluene cracking The experimental results indicate that the best cracking effect on toluene is achieved at a voltage of 7 kV. To further illustrate the mechanism, the current variation at different voltages and the current variation at different catalytic anodes at 7 kV were studied, and the results are shown in Fig. 9(a)-(c). It can be seen from Fig. 9(a) that the toluene cracking rate increases with increasing voltage and reaches the maximum at 7 kV. Continuing to increase the energy causes the toluene cracking rate to decrease instead. The reason may be that with the increase of voltage, the electrocatalytic activity in Ti-MnO2/La2O3/rGO is excited and the cracking ability of toluene is enhanced. At the same time, a large number of free radicals and reactive substances are generated by the voltage increase, and a chain reaction occurs with toluene, which greatly promotes the cracking of toluene, and the reaction equation is as follows[48–51]. (15) H•+H•→H2 (16) N•+H•→NH• (17) NH•+H•→NH2• (18) CH3•+H•→CH4 (19) CH3•+CH3•→C2H6 (20) CH2•+CH2•→C2H4 (21) Image 7 (22) Image 8 (23) Image 9 (24) Image 10 (25) Image 11 (26) Image 12 (27) Image 13 The current variation during the cracking of toluene by different catalytic anodes at 7 kV shows in Fig. S4. It can be seen from the figure that the current of Ti-MnO2 is the lowest and the current of Ti-MnO2/La2O3/rGO is the highest at the same voltage. Increasing La2O3 can reduce the catalytic anode resistance and increase the reaction current. In the meantime, it is evident from comparing Ti-MnO2/La2O3 and Ti-MnO2/La2O3/rGO that the addition of rGO increases the catalytic anode's current, suggesting that it does lower the resistance of the catalytic anode surface, improve the catalytic activity, and produce a more uniform current distribution. in line with the conclusions drawn in Section 3.3.1. Fig. S5 displays the current and energy consumption at various voltages. The findings indicate that the system's current value rises with voltage. Combined with the toluene cracking condition at different voltages, it shows that increasing the voltage does not effectively increase the toluene cracking. At the same time, increasing the voltage, the energy consumption increases, which is not conducive to the promotion of subsequent applications. At high voltage, the catalytic anode after the reaction was taken out, there was an obvious smell of burning, which indirectly proved that increasing the voltage would cause the catalyst on the electrode to sinter. 3.3.4 Effect of different anode substrates on toluene cracking To investigate the effect of different substrates on the cleavage, this experiment loaded MnO2/La2O3/rGO catalyst on porous titanium, porous nickel and nickel foam for the degradation of toluene, respectively. The findings were shown in Fig. 10. Due to the larger specific surface area and electrodeposition loading of the nickel foam than that of the porous nickel, the nickel foam substrate for toluene had a higher cracking efficiency than the porous nickel did. With time, the catalyst's capacity to bind toluene tended to saturate, which slowed the pace of deterioration. It is obvious that porous titanium served as the best substrate for toluene cleavage. As compared to nickel, titanium had superior chemical stability, lower resistance, and electrode electrochemical activity[52]. The titanium substrate, meantime, facilitated the charge transfer between Mn4+ and Mn3+, Mn2+, increasing the conductivity of the electrodes and possibly improving the MnO2/La2O3/rGO catalyst's capacity for charge transfer[53]. Different matrices degraded toluene in significantly different ways at the same pore structure, indicating that matrix-catalyst interactions may limit carbon deposition or boost the degradation activity of the catalysts. 3.4 Discharge process and cracking products 3.4.1 Toluene cracking product detection and mechanisms We checked the OES (Optical emission spectra) results obtained by several investigations conducted under comparable circumstances to investigate the species created by the plasma ( Table 3). It was confirmed that numerous energetic electrons and excited state species were involved in the cracking of toluene under the discharge regime and reduced the formation of by-products[54,55]. Fig. 11(a)-(c) shows the results of toluene cleavage products when Ti, Ti-MnO2, Ti-MnO2/La2O3/rGO were catalytic anodes at 7 kV, respectively. Table 4 shows the name, peak time and peak area of cracking products. The peak area represents the relative concentration of different products, the larger the peak area, the higher the content in the tail gas. According to the detection results, in an oxygen-free environment, the toluene cracking products were mainly unsaturated chain hydrocarbons and amides, including ethane, acetylene, methacrylic, methacrylate, benzene, benzamide, etc. In the case of pure Ti catalytic anode cracking, there were numerous and varied gaseous by-products. After adding MnO2 catalyst to the catalytic anode, the content of by-products was significantly reduced, showing that MnO2 may successfully reduce the content of gaseous by-products in the toluene cracking process. For the Ti-MnO2/La2O3/rGO catalytic anode, the lowest type and content of cracking byproducts were observed, and the lowest content of carbon accumulation precursors (C2H2, C2H4, etc.) were generated when comparing Ti and Ti-MnO2 catalytic anodes, indicating that Ti-MnO2/La2O3/rGO has good anti-carbon accumulation ability, which is consistent with the previous conclusions. According to the above experimental analysis, the cleavage of toluene in this experimental system is shown in Fig. 12. The presence of a large number of high-energy electrons and free radicals such as •H, •N and •N2 in the corona discharge region cleaves toluene into various fragments in steps. Due to the reduction reaction of unstable organic fragments mainly with •H, •N and •NH in an oxygen-free environment, small molecules of hydrocarbon organics are mainly formed. The MnO2/La2O3/rGO catalyst loaded on the anode surface has high catalytic activity. electrons are transferred through the valence change of Mn3+ and Mn4+ in MnO2 crystals. rGO improves the electron transfer ability on the catalyst surface and provides a fast transfer channel for electron transfer. La2O3 can make the adsorption product on the catalyst surface to transfer the CxHy and avoid carbon accumulation generation on the catalyst surface. 3.4.2 Corona discharge generates plasma and active components In order to verify the situation of various types of radicals produced by high voltage discharge during the reaction, physical field simulations of plasma generation by corona discharge on the horizontal cross section inside the reactor were calculated using COMSOL. Analysis of the electron distribution between cathode and anode at different times and distances at 7 kV voltage is helpful to analyze the plasma generation during the reaction. This simulation is computed using a simplified model that uses fluid-type equations to describe the properties of the charged material, assuming that the discharge is uniformly diffused in the radial direction. The electron density is calculated by solving the drift-diffusion equation for the electron density, the source coefficient is determined by the rate coefficient of the plasma chemistry, and the space charge density is calculated automatically from the plasma chemistry specified in the COMSOL model. The electrons move randomly within several mean free ranges on the reactor walls, causing their energy to be lost at the walls and again transferring energy through secondary emission effects, thus obtaining the electron flux boundary conditions. The equation for the mass fraction of non-electron matter and the boundary conditions are shown in the supporting material S1. Plasma discharge in nitrogen atmosphere is prone to hundreds of reactions. This simulation is mainly concerned with the density distribution of charges and the current potential distribution, so the reactions can be simplified and the production and disappearance of charged substances can be expressed through the main reactions occurring such as adsorption, ionization, and reaction, mainly including the following reactions: (28) e+A=>A++2e (29) e+A=>A- (30) e+2 A=>A-+A (31) e+A+=>A (32) A-+A+=>2 A Where A is N2, N2 can ionize into positive ion N2 + or attach electron to become negative ion N2 -. Where Eq. (28) is ionization reaction, Eqs. (29) and (30) is attachment reaction, and Eqs. (31) and (32) is inter-particle reaction. In addition the surface reactions of charged particles on the wall mainly include：. (33) A+=>A (34) A-=>A The adhesion coefficients of both surface reactions are 1. The secondary emission coefficient of positive ions is set to 0.05 at the boundary and 0 at the outer electrode, and the average electronic energy of secondary electrons is set to 4 eV. The potential distribution and electron density of the horizontal cross section inside the reactor during the discharge process are shown in Fig. 13(a)-(b). Fig. 13(a) shows the voltage distribution inside the reactor at 7 kV, the voltage near the cathode is close to 7 kV, and the voltage change is more obvious the closer to the anode. The voltage distribution inside the reactor is uniform and the discharge area is large. The high voltage area is mainly concentrated at and near the cathode, and an obvious inverted triangle area is formed between the cathode and the anode. Fig. 13(b) shows that the electron temperature during the discharge process is mainly concentrated in the cathode and the area between. The higher the electron temperature the higher the energy produced by the plasma, and the number and type of various active substances generated during the high voltage discharge increases. The high-energy electrons are widely distributed in the reaction process, and the energy change trend is obvious, indicating that the number of high-energy electrons generated during the discharge process is large and varied. To further investigate the density and generation changes of each positive and negative ions and electrons during the discharge process, the linear distance between the cathode and the three points of the vessel wall was simulated in two dimensions, and the results are shown in Fig. 14(a)-(d). Fig. 14(a)-(b) show the electron temperature and potential variation between the cathode and the wall line, and it can be seen that the results are consistent with those shown in the cross section. The voltage is maximum near the cathode, while the electron temperature is highest near the cathode and anode and low in the middle and the wall. Fig. 14(c)-(e) show the distribution of cations, anions and electrons between the two poles of the music, respectively. Fig. 14(c) shows that the cations are mainly distributed around the anode, producing violent energy fluctuations in the surrounding space and generating large amounts of cations, while the number of cations produced near the cathode gradually decreases. Fig. 14(d), in contrast to the cation, produces more anions near the cathode with obvious energy fluctuations. It indicates that the vicinity of the cathode is the main region of anion production and produces a large number of abundant types of anions. The electron distribution is shown in Fig. 14(e), from which it can be seen that the electron distribution region is mainly between the cathode and the vessel wall, and the large number of electrons generated has high energy, which can act on all kinds of gas molecules in the reaction region and produce a large number of free radicals and active substances. The electrical and potential conditions inside the reactor were simulated so as to compare the impacts of the addition of toluene and catalyst on the electric field created there. In order to simplify the calculations, for calculating the discharge at a straight line distance from the anode-cathode, the N2 gas mixture containing 500 ppm of toluene was approximated as a homogeneous gas with a temperature of 20 °C at atmospheric pressure, a molar mass of 28.32 kg/mol, a potential characteristic length of 5.349 m, and a Lennard-Jones potential parameter of 379.83 K. The potential of the gas was calculated as follows. The simulation results of the ion concentration are shown in Fig. 15(a) and Fig. 15(c), after the addition of toluene, the concentration of negative ions in the reaction vessel increases and is mainly concentrated near the cathode (Fig. 15(c)). Due to the electrophilic nature of toluene, it mainly aggregates and undergoes ionization at the cathode, generating more active species. However, the concentration of toluene is small and has no significant effect on the potential distribution, electron density, and electron temperature in the whole discharge system (Fig. S6(a), (c), (e)). Next, the addition of catalyst was simulated and the anode material was set to be a mixture of MnO2La2O3 known from the COMSOL built-in materials library. As shown in Figs. 15(b) and 15(d), the concentration of positive and negative ions slightly decreased after the addition of the catalyst, which may be attributed to the decrease in electrical conductivity compared to the metal Ti with the addition of oxides to the catalyst, resulting in weakening the surface electrical energy of the catalyst. Figs. S6(b), (d), (f) shows that the potential distribution, electron density, and electron temperature of the whole system did not change significantly, which is due to the excessive voltage and thin catalyst layer, which has no effect on the overall discharge. Further, a microscopic simulation of the potential and electron density distribution of the gas plasma discharge localized above the catalyst after the addition of the catalyst was performed. Based on the SEM results, the catalyst thickness in this simulation was set to 50 nm, the width of the catalyst block was set to (from left to right) 30 nm, 50 nm, 40 nm, and 10 nm, and the gap between catalysts was set to (from left to right) 15 nm,11,10,9, and 15 nm, with no change in the catalyst material and gas conditions. As shown in Fig. 16(a)-(b), due to the thin bottom of the catalyst layer thickness, it has little effect on the potential distribution within the whole system. As can be seen in Fig. 16(c)-(d), the surface electron density of the loaded catalyst is obviously elevated, which is due to the many defective sites on the surface of the catalyst, forming many sectors and gaps, which makes the catalyst activity enhanced. It indicates that the loaded catalyst can promote the generation of electrons and energy and effectively improve the cracking efficiency of toluene. 4 Conclusion In this study, the catalyst was directly loaded on the anode and coupled with plasma technology for tar cracking for the first time, and the findings revealed that the catalyst surface had a high cracking efficiency. At 7 kV, the MnO2/La2O3/rGO catalyst on porous titanium mesh achieved a 90% cracking efficiency. CV curves were used to further confirm the optimum proportion of each component in the electrodeposition process. Combined with the analysis of cracking products, it is shown that MnO2 can effectively improve toluene cracking efficiency, La2O3 can effectively alleviate the generation of carbon deposition, rGO addition can effectively increase the current in corona discharge process, promote electron transfer. In addition, COMSOL was used to simulate the corona discharge in the homemade reactor. The electric potential distribution on the horizontal section of the reactor showed that the corona discharge area was large and the electric potential distribution was uniform. The presence of toluene and catalyst greatly boosted the concentration of ions near the cathode and the number of electrons on the catalyst surface. This led to a substantial increase in the variety and quantity of active particles, which can effectively increase the types and numbers of active species and enhance electron collisions and ionization. This study's toluene cracking regularity applies to biphenyls and PAHs as well, offering a practical way to break tar bonds. This research holds considerable promise for the oxygen-free secondary use of tar in cracked gas and coke oven gas. The catalyst can effectively reduce the inevitable carbon building issue in organic gas reactions, and the rGo addition offers a fresh approach to the catalyst sintering problem. Moreover, the catalyst is directly loaded on the anode surface by electrodeposition, which can significantly reduce the process flow and facilitate the practical operation. In the future, more screening will be done to find catalysts with high catalytic activity, resistance to high voltage, and extended effective times. coredata.dc:description: To achieve the purification of coke oven gas and pyrolysis gas under oxygen-free conditions, the MnO2/La2O3/rGO composite catalyst was innovatively loaded directly onto the surface of porous titanium mesh anode by electrodeposition in this study, together with corona discharge for toluene cracking. During the catalyst preparation, the effects of potential and pH on the catalyst were verified in combination with cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves. The results showed that the toluene cracking rate reached 90% at 7 kV when the electrolyte concentrations of Mn2+, La3+ and rGO were 0.1 mol/L, 0.05 mol/L and 0.005 g/L, respectively. In addition, in this study, the distribution and changes of potential and electron temperature inside the reactor were simulated by COMSOL, and the concentration and change pattern of positive and negative ions at 7 kV were calculated. The results showed that both the plasma and the catalyst play a very significant role in this process.
coredata.dc:title: MnO2/La2O3/rGO composite catalyst prepared by electrodeposition as corona discharge anode for electrocatalytic cracking of toluene
